messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 54 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: CarFi: Rider Localization Using Wi-Fi CSI

Paper Abstract: Abstract. With the rise of hailing services, people are increasingly relying on shared mobility (e.g., Uber, Lyft) drivers to pick up for transportation. However, such drivers and riders have difficulties finding each other in urban areas as GPS signals get blocked by skyscrapers, in crowded environments (e.g., in stadiums, airports, and bars), at night, and in bad weather. It wastes their time, creates a bad user experience, and causes more CO2 emissions due to idle driving. In this work, we explore the potential of Wi-Fi to help drivers to determine the street side of the riders. Our proposed system is called CarFi that uses Wi-Fi CSI from two antennas placed inside a moving vehicle and a data-driven technique to determine the street side of the rider. By collecting real-world data in realistic and challenging settings by blocking the signal with other people and other parked cars, we see that CarFi is 95.44% accurate in rider-side determination in both line of sight (LoS) and non-line of sight (nLoS) conditions, and can be run on an embedded GPU in real-time.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 54 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 54"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Uber Compass, an AR UX/UI Case Study.",
        "WiFi, 12dBi, 180 degree directional antenna.",
        "WiFi Directional 10 DBi Panel Antenna.",
        "RFCam: Uncertainty-aware Fusion of Camera and Wi-Fi for Real-time Human Identification with Mobile Devices.",
        "High precision human detection and tracking using millimeter-wave radars.",
        "Indoor Intelligent Vehicle localization using WiFi Received Signal Strength Indicator.",
        "EyeFi: Fast Human Identification Through Vision and WiFi-based Trajectory Matching.",
        "Fusing WiFi and camera for fast motion tracking and person identification: Demo abstract.",
        "Person tracking and identification using cameras and Wi-Fi Channel State Information (CSI) from smartphones: dataset.",
        "Dataset: Occupancy detection, tracking, and estimation using a vertically mounted depth sensor.",
        "Occutherm: Occupant thermal comfort inference using body shape information.",
        "Tool release: Gathering 802.11 n traces with channel state information.",
        "Tool Release: Gathering 802.11n Traces with Channel State Information.",
        "MagTrack: Enabling safe driving monitoring with wearable magnetics.",
        "Wi-Go: Accurate and scalable vehicle positioning using WiFi Fine Timing Measurement.",
        "Towards 3D human pose construction using WiFi.",
        "3d reconstruction using deep learning: a survey.",
        "SpotFi: Decimeter level localization using WiFi.",
        "ID-Match: A hybrid computer vision and RFID system for recognizing individuals in groups.",
        "Long term occupancy estimation in a commercial space: an empirical study.",
        "COD: a dataset of commercial building occupancy traces.",
        "Efficient global 2d-3d matching for camera localization in a large-scale 3d map.",
        "Recognizing individuals in groups in outdoor environments combining stereo vision, RFID and BLE.",
        "WiFi sensing with Channel State Information: A survey.",
        "Signfi: Sign language recognition using WiFi.",
        "ODDS: real-time object detection using depth sensors on embedded GPUs.",
        "Measuring people-flow through doorways using easy-to-install IR array sensors.",
        "Real-time fine grained occupancy estimation using depth sensors on ARM embedded platforms.",
        "Dataset: Inferring thermal comfort using body shape information utilizing depth sensors.",
        "FORK: Fine grained Occupancy estimatoR using Kinect on ARM embedded platforms.",
        "WiFi fingerprinting localization for intelligent vehicles in car park.",
        "Accurate ubiquitous localization with off-the-shelf ieee 802.11 ac devices.",
        "Exploring mmWave Radar and Camera Fusion for High-Resolution and Long-Range Depth Imaging.",
        "A review of cognitive assistants for healthcare: Trends, prospects, and future directions.",
        "About face: A survey of facial recognition evaluation.",
        "Multiple emitter location and signal parameter estimation.",
        "Nexmon: The c-based firmware patching framework, 2017.",
        "Multipath Triangulation: Decimeter-level WiFi Localization and Orientation with a Single Unaided Receiver.",
        "Deep multi-view feature learning for person re-identification.",
        "Fundamentals of wireless communication.",
        "Decimeter-level localization with a single WiFi access point.",
        "Robust Chinese remainder theorem ranging method based on dual-frequency measurements.",
        "Insight: recognizing humans without face recognition.",
        "Learning content and style: Joint action recognition and person identification from human skeletons.",
        "LiFS: low human-effort, device-free localization with fine-grained subcarrier information.",
        "On the effectiveness of low-rank matrix factorization for LSTM model compression.",
        "Widir: walking direction estimation using wireless signals.",
        "Real-time human detection using contour cues.",
        "Precise power delay profiling with commodity Wi-Fi.",
        "Arraytrack: A fine-grained indoor location system.",
        "WiFi sensing-based real-time bus tracking and arrival time prediction in urban environments.",
        "mID: Tracking and identifying people with millimeter wave radar.",
        "To prune, or not to prune: exploring the efficacy of pruning for model compression.",
        "Fast human detection using a cascade of histograms of oriented gradients."
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 54 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in CarFi: Rider Localization Using Wi-Fi CSI, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
